content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 42$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 42$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 12$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

As a human player, I would choose a strategy that maximizes my earnings over the 75 rounds of the game. Given the payoff structure, it seems that both choices have their advantages and disadvantages.

If I always pick R (R{}), my opponent will likely pick B when they see me choosing R consistently, as this would result in a higher payout for them. This would mean that in most cases, I would get 0$ while they would get 42$. However, if I manage to surprise them with an occasional B choice, I could potentially earn 45$ in those rounds.

On the other hand, if I always pick B (B{}), my opponent will likely pick R when they see me choosing B consistently, as this would result in a higher payout for them. In most cases, I would get 12$ while they would get 45$. However, if I manage to surprise them with an occasional R choice, I could potentially earn 42$ in those rounds.

To maximize my earnings, it seems reasonable to mix my choices between R and B to make it harder for the opponent to predict my next move. One possible strategy is to follow a random or quasi-random pattern, which could help me earn more 45$ payouts when the opponent least expects it. However, without knowing the specific rules governing my opponent's behavior (e.g., are they also allowed to change their strategy over time?), I cannot definitively say what the optimal strategy would be in this game. But I would choose a mixed strategy, leaning towards R more often due to its higher payout when successful.

So, for the next round, I would choose R (R{}). Of course, this choice carries the risk of my opponent switching to R as well, resulting in a payout of 12$ for both of us. But the potential reward of earning 45$ makes it an appealing option to consider. It's important to remember that this game is played over many rounds, and my goal is to maximize my earnings over the entirety of the experiment.
